File Naming Conventions

STM Guidelines

Glossary

On this page

Glossary ​

A ​

ACL (Annual Copyright License) : A blanket license from CCC that covers routine internal copying and sharing of published content within an organization.

Adaptation : A modification or derivative work based on an original copyrighted work.

Author Agreement : The contract between an author and publisher that specifies copyright ownership and rights transfers.

B ​

Blanket License : A license that covers multiple uses or items under a single agreement, typically for an annual fee.

C ​

CC (Creative Commons) : A nonprofit organization that provides free, standardized licenses for creators to share their work with specific permissions.

CC-BY : Creative Commons Attribution license - allows reuse with attribution.

CC-BY-NC : Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial - allows non-commercial reuse with attribution.

CCC (Copyright Clearance Center) : A licensing organization that facilitates copyright compliance through various licensing solutions.

Copyright : Legal protection for original works of authorship, giving the creator exclusive rights to use and distribute.

Copyright Notice : A statement indicating copyright ownership, typically "© [Year] [Owner]".

Corresponding Author : The author designated to handle communications about a publication, often the contact for permissions.

D ​

Derivative Work : A new work based on one or more existing copyrighted works.

DOI (Digital Object Identifier) : A unique alphanumeric string assigned to identify digital content and provide a permanent link.

E ​

ELSA : Elsevier Author Platform - self-service platform for authors.

EMSS : Electronic Manuscript Submission System - Elsevier's manuscript management system.

Embargo Period : A period during which content cannot be freely shared, often applied to Open Access articles.

Exclusive Rights : Rights granted to a single party, preventing others from the same use.

F ​

Fair Use : A US legal doctrine allowing limited use of copyrighted material without permission for purposes like criticism, education, or research.

FTE (Full-Time Equivalent) : A unit measuring workload equal to one full-time employee.

G ​

Gold OA : Open Access publishing where the article is immediately freely available, typically with author-paid fees.

Green OA : Open Access where authors self-archive their work in a repository, often after an embargo period.

Grant of Rights : Permission given by a rights holder to use their copyrighted material.

H ​

HCM (Health Content Management) : Elsevier's division managing health-related content.

HS (Health Sciences) : Division handling medical and healthcare-related permissions.

I ​

In-Copyright : A work that is still protected by copyright law.

Intellectual Property (IP) : Legal rights over creations of the mind, including copyrights, patents, and trademarks.

L ​

License : A legal agreement granting permission to use copyrighted material under specified conditions.

License Fee : Payment required to obtain permission to use copyrighted material.

M ​

Model Release : Written permission from a person appearing in a photo or video to use their likeness.

N ​

Non-Exclusive Rights : Rights that can be granted to multiple parties simultaneously.

O ​

OA (Open Access) : A publishing model where content is freely available to readers without subscription.

ORCID : Open Researcher and Contributor ID - a unique identifier for researchers.

P ​

Permission : Authorization from a rights holder to use copyrighted material.

PMID (PubMed ID) : A unique identifier for articles indexed in PubMed.

PMC (PubMed Central) : NIH's free archive of biomedical and life sciences literature.

Public Domain : Works not protected by copyright, freely available for use.

R ​

Republication : Using previously published content in a new publication.

Rights Holder : The person or entity that owns the copyright to a work.

RightsLink : CCC's online licensing platform for purchasing permissions.

RPC (Rights & Permissions Collector) : Elsevier's system of record for managing permissions.

Rule of 10 : Policy requiring publisher contact when requesting 10+ items from the same source.

S ​

S&T (Science & Technology) : Division handling scientific and technical permissions.

SHERPA/RoMEO : Database of publisher copyright and self-archiving policies.

STM : International Association of Scientific, Technical and Medical Publishers.

STM Guidelines : Framework for reasonable reuse of content between STM publishers.

System of Record : The authoritative data source for a given data element (RPC for permissions).

T ​

Territory : Geographic scope of a license (e.g., worldwide, North America only).

Tier : Classification level for permission requests based on complexity.

Transfer of Copyright : When an author assigns their copyright to a publisher.

U ​

Usage Rights : Specific permissions for how content may be used (print, electronic, translations, etc.).

W ​

Work for Hire : Work created by an employee within scope of employment, with copyright owned by employer.

World Rights : License granting permission for use anywhere in the world.

Abbreviations Quick Reference ​
